title: ORD Scientific and Technical Work Products Clearance Policy and Procedures

field_policy_statement.value:
All Office of Research and Development (ORD) final draft and final scientific and technical work products will be approved by the appropriate level of ORD management prior to being published, issued, exhibited, or presented by or on behalf of ORD outside of the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA)*.  Approval will be documented through the Scientific and Technical Information Clearance System (STICS).   

More broadly, ORD’s policy is to maintain a comprehensive process for the release of scientific and technical work products that:  1) provides for the preparation, review and clearance of scientific and technical work products developed as part of the employee’s official duties; 2) conforms to the guidance in the EPA Peer Review Handbook; 3) verifies that applicable Quality Assurance (QA) requirements have been met; 4) provides for advance notification to the Immediate Office of the Assistant Administrator (IOAA) and relevant program and regional offices prior to the release of products that meet the advance notification criteria; and 5) ensures that STICS and the Science Inventory (SI) are used to track, clear, store and make publicly available the scientific and technical work products.

*Internal reports also must be cleared. These reports are typically developed in response to a request from a program or regional office, submitted only to the requester, and not intended for external publication. These products may be made public by inclusion in a rulemaking docket.
field_policy_statement.safe_value:
All Office of Research and Development (ORD) final draft and final scientific and technical work products will be approved by the appropriate level of ORD management prior to being published, issued, exhibited, or presented by or on behalf of ORD outside of the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA)*.  Approval will be documented through the Scientific and Technical Information Clearance System (STICS).   

More broadly, ORD’s policy is to maintain a comprehensive process for the release of scientific and technical work products that:  1) provides for the preparation, review and clearance of scientific and technical work products developed as part of the employee’s official duties; 2) conforms to the guidance in the EPA Peer Review Handbook; 3) verifies that applicable Quality Assurance (QA) requirements have been met; 4) provides for advance notification to the Immediate Office of the Assistant Administrator (IOAA) and relevant program and regional offices prior to the release of products that meet the advance notification criteria; and 5) ensures that STICS and the Science Inventory (SI) are used to track, clear, store and make publicly available the scientific and technical work products.

*Internal reports also must be cleared. These reports are typically developed in response to a request from a program or regional office, submitted only to the requester, and not intended for external publication. These products may be made public by inclusion in a rulemaking docket.

field_related_procedures.title: ORD Scientific and Technical Work Product Clearance Procedures

field_policy_background.value:
ORD scientific and technical work products provide critical information to environmental decision makers and the scientific community.  As a result, ORD has a responsibility to release scientific and technical work products in a timely way while ensuring that they adhere to the highest standards of technical rigor and scientific integrity.  The clearance process serves as a final check that these standards have been met.  In addition, EPA Order 2200.4a, EPA Publication Review Procedure, establishes policy and procedural requirements for the review, clearance, and publication of materials published or issued by the EPA, and requires Assistant Administrators (AAs) to establish internal review procedures and controls to assure the high quality of their products. 

ORD established these procedures to standardize the clearance process.  This document will assist with processing required clearance through STICS.  Responsibility for review and final approval depends on the type of product.  Go to this site for additional information on STICS: https://intranet.ord.epa.gov/science/scientific-technical-information-clearance-system.

taxonomy.name: Scientific and Technical Information Clearance System

title: Extramural Management Policy - Delegations of Authority

field_policy_statement.value: It is ORD policy that all extramural instruments are managed in such a manner as to promote the highest level of scientific and engineering excellence while adhering to all applicable Federal and Agency regulations, policies, procedures and guidance.  The extramural delegations of authority, as stated in this policy, will serve to facilitate proper extramural management integrity.
field_policy_statement.safe_value: It is ORD policy that all extramural instruments are managed in such a manner as to promote the highest level of scientific and engineering excellence while adhering to all applicable Federal and Agency regulations, policies, procedures and guidance.  The extramural delegations of authority, as stated in this policy, will serve to facilitate proper extramural management integrity.

field_policy_background.value: ORD Policy Transmittal 98-P-3 (February 1998), and its amendment (March 1998), established ORD’s extramural delegations of authority, which were later included in section 4.2 of the ORD Policy and Procedures Manual.  Chapter 4, Section V.D.4, of the ORD Policy and Procedures manual established delegations of authority and procedure for Memoranda of Understanding (MOU) in February 2006.  This ORD policy consolidates and updates the extramural delegations of authority to comply with Agency and Federal guidance.  The procedures from Chapter 4, Section V.D.4, will be published and maintained separately from the policy documents.
field_policy_background.safe_value: ORD Policy Transmittal 98-P-3 (February 1998), and its amendment (March 1998), established ORD’s extramural delegations of authority, which were later included in section 4.2 of the ORD Policy and Procedures Manual.  Chapter 4, Section V.D.4, of the ORD Policy and Procedures manual established delegations of authority and procedure for Memoranda of Understanding (MOU) in February 2006.  This ORD policy consolidates and updates the extramural delegations of authority to comply with Agency and Federal guidance.  The procedures from Chapter 4, Section V.D.4, will be published and maintained separately from the policy documents.

This ORD policy supplements Agency and Federal guidance for extramural instruments.
field_policy_statement.safe_value: It is ORD policy that all extramural instruments are managed in such a manner as to promote the highest level of scientific and engineering excellence while adhering to all applicable Federal and Agency regulations, policies, procedures and guidance. This ORD policy supplements Agency and Federal guidance for extramural instruments.

field_related_procedures.title: Extramural Procedures and Applicable Agency Guidance

field_policy_background.value: Extramural Policy applicable to ORD is primarily contained in Agency and Federal Policy. ORD Extramural Policy defines ORD roles and responsibilities and establishes ORD delegations for approval levels. The ORD specific procedures for implementing Federal and Agency Policies are maintained as a separate management document.
field_policy_background.safe_value: Extramural Policy applicable to ORD is primarily contained in Agency and Federal Policy. ORD Extramural Policy defines ORD roles and responsibilities and establishes ORD delegations for approval levels. The ORD specific procedures for implementing Federal and Agency Policies are maintained as a separate management document.

field_policy_statement.value: ORD pays for IT assets provisioned for employees during the onboarding process. When these employees leave ORD via transfer or departure from EPA, certain facility and network access privileges and the IT asset costs continue until a deprovision request is processed. During the ORD deprovisioning process, a series of actions and alerts for action occur. To optimize cost savings, facilitate required file preservation, better ameliorate security risks, and comply with EPA policy requirements, specific actions must be taken using the dPROV application to deprovision departing/departed federal and non-federal ORD employees on or before their separation date. Additionally, departing federal ORD staff who are expected to return in an official capacity at a future date must be deprovisioned using the dPROV application upon departure.  Continuation of LAN access and EZTech computer charges while awaiting approval to bring the person back onboard must be approved in writing by the appropriate LCO Deputy Director for Management.  See Appendix A for a general flowchart of deprovisioning steps.
field_policy_statement.safe_value: ORD pays for IT assets provisioned for employees during the onboarding process. When these employees leave ORD via transfer or departure from EPA, certain facility and network access privileges and the IT asset costs continue until a deprovision request is processed. During the ORD deprovisioning process, a series of actions and alerts for action occur. To optimize cost savings, facilitate required file preservation, better ameliorate security risks, and comply with EPA policy requirements, specific actions must be taken using the dPROV application to deprovision departing/departed federal and non-federal ORD employees on or before their separation date. Additionally, departing federal ORD staff who are expected to return in an official capacity at a future date must be deprovisioned using the dPROV application upon departure.  Continuation of LAN access and EZTech computer charges while awaiting approval to bring the person back onboard must be approved in writing by the appropriate LCO Deputy Director for Management.  See Appendix A for a general flowchart of deprovisioning steps.

field_related_procedures.title: ORD policy "Deprovisioning ORD Staff" Appendix A

field_policy_background.value:
The Office of Research and Development includes federal and non-federal staff who work onsite in facilities across the nation and in offsite locations. Onboarding steps (e.g., personnel security database entry, requesting provisioning of IT assets, etc.) are most often taken in a timely fashion to meet all onboarding requirements and better ensure a timely start to the employee’s work.

 

With this policy, ORD is highlighting the Agency’s requirement (see EPA Order 3110.5A) that deprovisioning actions be taken on or before the date that an employee separates from ORD, but in no event more than 24 hours after the employee’s departure. In this way, ORD will avoid unnecessary Working Capital Fund (WCF) costs and will reduce the security and property risks associated with untended IT assets and accounts. LCO Management needs to determine the best practices within their sphere of operations to ensure that this policy is met in all cases.

In this way, ORD will avoid unnecessary Working Capital Fund (WCF) costs and will reduce the security and property risks associated with untended IT assets and accounts. taxonomy.name: LCO Provisioning Points of Contact or Requesters and LCO Provisioning Approvers

title: Provisioning of IT Assets for ORD Staff

field_policy_statement.value: ORD pays for IT assets that are registered to employees during the onboarding and provisioning process. An employee must have an active work force ID (WFID) and completed background investigation for IT assets and space to be allocated. Additionally, all non-federal employees need to be affiliated with an active OASIS “contract” to work at EPA. An OASIS “contract” must reflect an underlying, approved, valid extramural or other vehicle to bring people onboard and provision them.
field_policy_statement.safe_value: ORD pays for IT assets that are registered to employees during the onboarding and provisioning process. An employee must have an active work force ID (WFID) and completed background investigation for IT assets and space to be allocated. Additionally, all non-federal employees need to be affiliated with an active OASIS “contract” to work at EPA. An OASIS “contract” must reflect an underlying, approved, valid extramural or other vehicle to bring people onboard and provision them.

field_policy_background.value: The Office of Research and Development includes federal and non-federal staff who work onsite in EPA facilities across the nation and in some cases non-EPA locations. Onboarding steps must be taken in a timely fashion to better ensure a quick start to the employee’s work, but also must meet all onboarding requirements. LCO managers are asked to create best practices within their scope of operations to ensure that this policy is met in every case.

LCO managers are asked to create best practices within their scope of operations to ensure that this policy is met in every case.

field_policy_statement.value: This policy establishes ORD's delegations for IM/IT acquisitions.
field_policy_statement.safe_value: This policy establishes ORD's delegations for IM/IT acquisitions.

field_policy_background.value:
The laws, Executive Orders and regulations which give EPA its authority typically, but not always, indicate that "the Administrator shall" exercise certain authorities. Official delegations of authority represent the basic direction to senior Headquarters and Regional management officials to exercise these delegated authorities. It is EPA's policy that, in order for other Agency management officials to act on behalf of the Administrator, the authority granted by Congress or the Executive Branch must be delegated officially. This is accomplished through the Agency's delegation process, and the "EPA Delegations Manual" and Interim Policy Notices serve as records of the authority of an Agency employee or representative to act on behalf of the Administrator.

Similarly, it is the policy of the ORD’s Office of Science Information Management (OSIM) that, in order for other OSIM officials to act on behalf of the ORD Senior Information Official (SIO) and Information Management Officer (IMO), the authority granted by the EPA Administrator, the EPA Chief Information Officer (CIO), and the ORD Assistant Administrator must be delegated officially.

Each SIO has been delegated authority, per the EPA CIO, to purchase non-traditional IT acquisitions (e.g., scientific equipment). Non-traditional acquisitions require security review, per ORD procedure, prior to the SIO review and approval or declination.

Agency delegations are accomplished through official Delegations and Re-Delegations. The SIO and IMO internal re-delegations (see ORD Local IMO delegations memo, Appendix A) serve as a record of the authority of an OSIM official to act on behalf of the ORD SIO or IMO.

field_policy_statement.value: ORD policy is to manage scientific data in a manner that: 1) recognizes scientific data as an asset; 2) considers data value and costs; and 3) is consistent across the organization.
field_policy_statement.safe_value: ORD policy is to manage scientific data in a manner that: 1) recognizes scientific data as an asset; 2) considers data value and costs; and 3) is consistent across the organization.

field_policy_background.value:
In response to Agency priorities, technological advances, and the need for new approaches to science, ORD scientists are conducting an array of innovative, creative, and collaborative projects. This work has resulted in a dramatic surge in the creation of scientific data. ORD is issuing the SDM Policy to address this trend.

The SDM Policy and its related procedures and guidance result from a comprehensive effort to gather input from ORD researchers and other staff about how they are currently performing SDM and barriers they have experienced. A representative group of researchers, science managers, and data managers served in a work group to draft the policy text. Next came a phase of interviews with more than 60 ORD researchers, data managers, science managers, and quality assurance managers to gather additional input. Information drawn from these interviews contributed heavily to the development of the SDM Guidance Handbook.

The SDM Policy promotes a consistent organizational approach to SDM in ORD with a primary focus on writing a Scientific Data Management Plan (SDMP) for every research effort that requires a QAPP. The SDMP expands upon previously existing requirements by including a data management component in the QAPP. A consistent approach to SDM can begin to solve the following concerns:

  • Inability of resources to keep pace with size and rate of scientific data growth.
  • Inefficiencies, such as duplication of efforts, the costs of unnecessary data retention, and inaccessibility of data.
  • Barriers to productive collaboration due to inconsistent SDM practices across ORD.

Both individual researchers and ORD as a whole could see many benefits from meeting these challenges through SDM, including:

  • Consistent management of scientific data across ORD can create an environment that enables the introduction of digital tools [e.g., data repositories, and Laboratory Information Management Systems (LIMS)].
  • Access to ORD data for use by other ORD scientists and stakeholders can be enhanced through SDM practices.
  • Consistent SDM can facilitate collaboration across disciplines; ORD labs, centers, and offices; and other agencies and entities.

field_policy_statement.value: This standard operating procedure (SOP) provides international travelers from the Office of Research and Development (ORD) with instructions to meet EPA’s overarching international travel procedure for mobile devices.
field_policy_statement.safe_value: This standard operating procedure (SOP) provides international travelers from the Office of Research and Development (ORD) with instructions to meet EPA’s overarching international travel procedure for mobile devices.

field_related_procedures.title: ORD PPM 9.15 "Mobile Devices for International Travel" (refer to pp.5-7)

field_policy_background.value:
Transport of government-furnished mobile devices outside of the United States and its territories without explicit authorization and security clearance in advance of travel is prohibited by EPA and federal policy. This requirement is in effect regardless of the traveler’s work status or international travel destination. Failure to comply with these requirements exposes employees to potential adverse administrative actions for misuse of government furnished equipment, information security policy violations and financial obligation for government costs incurred due to international transport and/or use.

This standard operating procedure has been developed to help ORD staff comply with EPA’s published procedure on mobile device use during international travel. While the broad term “mobile device” is used throughout the associated EPA procedure, only two specially-configured mobile devices are currently available for loan from EPA for international use: specially-configured loaner laptops and mobile devices with the international features applied. If needed, ORD Laboratories, Centers and Offices (LCOs) may purchase encrypted mobile devices such as USB flash drives and USB large-capacity external hard drives to meet EPA procedures SC-12 and SC-13 specifications.

Whether a traveler must use specially-configured mobile devices instead of standard-issue devices depends upon the risk level ruling provided by the EPA Senior Agency Information Security Officer (SAISO). The SAISO determines the IT risk level, either high or low, at destination cities. While on international travel to high-risk locations, only a specially-configured loaner laptop or a specially-configured loaner mobile device (with the international features applied) may be used to conduct official EPA business. However, use of other U.S. Government resources (e.g., Department of State or Department of Defense), is permitted for operational necessity and emergencies. While on international travel to international locations ruled by the SAISO to be low-risk, standard-issue EPA laptops, mobile phones and storage devices may be used.

This procedure covers all EPA-issued mobile devices, such as laptops, mobile phones and other mobile devices which store, process, transmit, or receive EPA information when such devices are used or carried on international travel. Direct travel to and from, and within U.S. territories and commonwealths is not considered international travel. This procedure applies to all ORD employees, contractors, and other users of ORD mobile devices who travel to international destinations on official business or for personal reasons.

Other related Federal and EPA policies (e.g., de minimis use) should be referred to directly for additional specific guidance.

title: ORD Implementation of the EPA Quality Assurance Field Activities Procedures

field_policy_statement.value: The Office of Research and Development (ORD) will satisfy the requirements stated in the EPA Field Activities Procedure Quality Assurance (QA) (CIO 2105-P-02.0) using the procedures described below.
field_policy_statement.safe_value: The Office of Research and Development (ORD) will satisfy the requirements stated in the EPA Field Activities Procedure Quality Assurance (QA) (CIO 2105-P-02.0) using the procedures described below.

field_related_procedures.title: ORD Implementation of the EPA Quality Assurance Field Activities Procedure

field_policy_background.value:
This PPM describes how ORD will meet the requirements of the EPA Quality Assurance Field Activities Procedure (QAFAP) (9).  ORD will rely on existing policies and procedures where available and create new procedures only when necessary to meet the requirements of the EPA QAFAP.  Field activities constitute one portion of ORD’s multidisciplinary and constantly changing research portfolio.  As such, ORD’s field activities procedures will draw on broader science management systems whenever possible and will rely on the Principal Investigator (PI) as the focal point for implementing these procedures.

This PPM has been developed for ORD employees for internal management purposes. It does not create any rights, substantive or procedural, enforceable at law. ORD may periodically revise this PPM to make improvements and/or to reflect changes in ORD policy.

If, on a case by case basis, an ORD employee chooses to vary from a provision of this PPM because it is determined to be inappropriate, inadequate and/or impractical, such variance shall be explained and documented. Choosing to vary from, or inadvertently failing to follow, a provision of this PPM shall not disqualify information obtained for any purpose including administrative or judicial proceedings.
field_policy_background.safe_value:
This PPM describes how ORD will meet the requirements of the EPA Quality Assurance Field Activities Procedure (QAFAP) (9).  ORD will rely on existing policies and procedures where available and create new procedures only when necessary to meet the requirements of the EPA QAFAP.  Field activities constitute one portion of ORD’s multidisciplinary and constantly changing research portfolio.  As such, ORD’s field activities procedures will draw on broader science management systems whenever possible and will rely on the Principal Investigator (PI) as the focal point for implementing these procedures.

title: Audits of Technical and Quality Systems

field_policy_statement.value: It is ORD policy to audit the technical and quality systems of intramural and extramural organizations that are collecting and using environmental data for EPA. The purpose of the audits is to demonstrate that the environmental data are being collected and used in a manner consistent with EPA's quality system and the organizations' systematic planning documents [i.e., quality management plans (QMPs), quality assurance project plans (QAPPs), and standard operating procedures (SOPs)].
field_policy_statement.safe_value: It is ORD policy to audit the technical and quality systems of intramural and extramural organizations that are collecting and using environmental data for EPA. The purpose of the audits is to demonstrate that the environmental data are being collected and used in a manner consistent with EPA's quality system and the organizations' systematic planning documents [i.e., quality management plans (QMPs), quality assurance project plans (QAPPs), and standard operating procedures (SOPs)].

field_related_procedures.title: Audits of Technical and Quality Systems

field_policy_background.value:
An audit is a tool for evaluating the technical and quality systems of environmental data collection or environmental data use. It is primarily a management tool and secondarily a technical tool. It is not a tool for individual employee appraisal. As a component of the EPA Quality System, the audit enables management to determine whether the systems are being implemented as planned. It also establishes the basis for taking action to correct any deficiencies that are discovered. A well-planned and carefully-conducted audit will minimize the collection or use of invalid data and prevent costly rework. Audits are most useful in addressing the following questions:

  • Does the system comply with its quality assurance (QA) and related planning documents?
  • Are the procedures defined in these documents implemented effectively?
  • Are the existing procedures effective in achieving the system's quality goals?
  • Are the environmental data collected in the system scientifically defensible?

The major types of audits that are performed in individual ORD organizations are described in the ORD QMP and include the following:

Quality System Audit (QSA) is an evaluation of an organization’s practices as they relate to its quality system, rather than its technical systems, for environmental data collection. It seeks to determine if a quality system is implemented and is operating in the manner prescribed by the organization’s or program’s approved QMP. According to ANSI/ASQC E4-2014 (8), assessments of environmental programs should be conducted periodically to measure the effectiveness of the programs’ quality systems. This requirement has been invoked as part of EPA Order CIO 2105.0 (5). Refer to EPA QA/G-3 (3), Guidance on Assessing Quality Systems, for further information about QSAs.

Technical Systems Audit (TSA) is a qualitative, on-site evaluation of an environmental data collection research effort. The objective of a TSA is to evaluate all facilities, measurement instrumentation, operating procedures, reporting requirements, and quality control (QC) procedures. The justification and audit standard for the TSA is typically the approved QAPP for the project. Refer to EPA QA/G-7 (4), Guidance on Technical Audits and Related Assessments for Environmental Data Operations, for further information about TSAs.

Surveillance is the on-site observation by QA staff, of ongoing environmental data collection to document conformance with applicable requirements and/or procedures, such as those given in a laboratory/facility manual, QAPP or SOP. It is focused on a specific technical activity, rather than on the entire technical system. It is typically less formal than other types of audits, but it should also include appropriate preparation, conducting, reporting, and follow-up phases. It may be helpful for verifying the adequacy of new laboratory operations, including analysts running new methods or using new instrumentation. The justification for and the audit standard for the surveillance is typically identified in the approved QAPP for the project.

Notebook Review is an independent examination of research notebooks while they are in use. The purpose of the review is to improve research documentation with the primary objective being to ensure elements of the research are documented and that the documentation allows peer researchers to understand and reproduce results. Each researcher must ensure the defensibility of data used to support EPA's regulatory mission. The review provides the QA staff, supervisor, mentor or PI feedback on items in the research notebook that may affect data quality and study re-constructability. The review applies to the bound paper notebooks; ring binder notebooks for data and field sheets; and electronic notebooks, all of which have a slightly different manner in which they are reviewed. Refer to PPM 13.2 (6), Paper Laboratory Records and PPM 13.6 (8), Scientific Recordkeeping: Electronic for further information about the reviews.

Proficiency/Performance Evaluation (PE) is a quantitative evaluation of a technical system or component thereof to evaluate the proficiency of an analyst or laboratory. Quantitative data generated from the measurement of an independent reference standard are compared to the certified value for the standard. Alternatively, quantitative data generated from the system's measurement of an environmental sample are compared to data generated by an independent measurement of the same sample. The justification for and the audit standard for the PE typically is identified in the approved QAPP for the project. The PE may be used to demonstrate analyst proficiency with a given method prior to analyzing research samples. PE samples may be procured from accredited commercial sources or they may be prepared by the auditor. PE samples may be shipped to the auditee to be analyzed blind (certified value unknown) with the results reported to the auditor.

Audit of Data Quality (ADQ) is an independent examination of data after they have been collected and verified by project staff. It determines how well the technical system performed with respect to the performance goals specified in the QAPP and whether the data were accumulated, transferred, reduced, calculated, summarized, and reported correctly. The justification for and the audit standard for the ADQ typically is identified in the project's QAPP.

Data Quality Assessment (DQA) is a statistical and scientific evaluation of data sets to determine the validity and performance of the data collection design and statistical analysis and to determine the adequacy of the data set for its intended use. In ORD, data quality assessments are limited to those projects for which formal data quality objectives were developed. Refer to EPA QA/G-9R (2), Data Quality Assessment: A Reviewer’s Guide, for more information about DQAs.

Laboratory Competency Assessment (LCA) is an external technical evaluation of laboratory operations. Competency means that an organization has the equipment, instrumentation, staff, and demonstrated analyst proficiency needed to generate valid environmental measurement data that meet the project needs. Refer to PPM 13.10 (10), Laboratory Competency Assessments for further information about ORD’s use of LCAs.

Readiness Review is a technical audit that is planned and performed prior to the initiation of a project to verify that project management has brought the facility and/or applicable technical systems to a state of readiness to begin the project. EPA has not traditionally used readiness reviews, but the principles can be used to ensure that all parts of an EPA program are in place and ready for the start of a project. TSAs can be scheduled to serve as readiness reviews.
field_policy_background.safe_value:
An audit is a tool for evaluating the technical and quality systems of environmental data collection or environmental data use. It is primarily a management tool and secondarily a technical tool. It is not a tool for individual employee appraisal. As a component of the EPA Quality System, the audit enables management to determine whether the systems are being implemented as planned. It also establishes the basis for taking action to correct any deficiencies that are discovered. A well-planned and carefully-conducted audit will minimize the collection or use of invalid data and prevent costly rework. Audits are most useful in addressing the following questions:

  • Does the system comply with its quality assurance (QA) and related planning documents?
  • Are the procedures defined in these documents implemented effectively?
  • Are the existing procedures effective in achieving the system's quality goals?
  • Are the environmental data collected in the system scientifically defensible?

The major types of audits that are performed in individual ORD organizations are described in the ORD QMP and include the following:

Quality System Audit (QSA) is an evaluation of an organization’s practices as they relate to its quality system, rather than its technical systems, for environmental data collection. It seeks to determine if a quality system is implemented and is operating in the manner prescribed by the organization’s or program’s approved QMP. According to ANSI/ASQC E4-2014 (8), assessments of environmental programs should be conducted periodically to measure the effectiveness of the programs’ quality systems. This requirement has been invoked as part of EPA Order CIO 2105.0 (5). Refer to EPA QA/G-3 (3), Guidance on Assessing Quality Systems, for further information about QSAs.

Technical Systems Audit (TSA) is a qualitative, on-site evaluation of an environmental data collection research effort. The objective of a TSA is to evaluate all facilities, measurement instrumentation, operating procedures, reporting requirements, and quality control (QC) procedures. The justification and audit standard for the TSA is typically the approved QAPP for the project. Refer to EPA QA/G-7 (4), Guidance on Technical Audits and Related Assessments for Environmental Data Operations, for further information about TSAs.

Surveillance is the on-site observation by QA staff, of ongoing environmental data collection to document conformance with applicable requirements and/or procedures, such as those given in a laboratory/facility manual, QAPP or SOP. It is focused on a specific technical activity, rather than on the entire technical system. It is typically less formal than other types of audits, but it should also include appropriate preparation, conducting, reporting, and follow-up phases. It may be helpful for verifying the adequacy of new laboratory operations, including analysts running new methods or using new instrumentation. The justification for and the audit standard for the surveillance is typically identified in the approved QAPP for the project.

Notebook Review is an independent examination of research notebooks while they are in use. The purpose of the review is to improve research documentation with the primary objective being to ensure elements of the research are documented and that the documentation allows peer researchers to understand and reproduce results. Each researcher must ensure the defensibility of data used to support EPA's regulatory mission. The review provides the QA staff, supervisor, mentor or PI feedback on items in the research notebook that may affect data quality and study re-constructability. The review applies to the bound paper notebooks; ring binder notebooks for data and field sheets; and electronic notebooks, all of which have a slightly different manner in which they are reviewed. Refer to PPM 13.2 (6), Paper Laboratory Records and PPM 13.6 (8), Scientific Recordkeeping: Electronic for further information about the reviews.

Proficiency/Performance Evaluation (PE) is a quantitative evaluation of a technical system or component thereof to evaluate the proficiency of an analyst or laboratory. Quantitative data generated from the measurement of an independent reference standard are compared to the certified value for the standard. Alternatively, quantitative data generated from the system's measurement of an environmental sample are compared to data generated by an independent measurement of the same sample. The justification for and the audit standard for the PE typically is identified in the approved QAPP for the project. The PE may be used to demonstrate analyst proficiency with a given method prior to analyzing research samples. PE samples may be procured from accredited commercial sources or they may be prepared by the auditor. PE samples may be shipped to the auditee to be analyzed blind (certified value unknown) with the results reported to the auditor.

Audit of Data Quality (ADQ) is an independent examination of data after they have been collected and verified by project staff. It determines how well the technical system performed with respect to the performance goals specified in the QAPP and whether the data were accumulated, transferred, reduced, calculated, summarized, and reported correctly. The justification for and the audit standard for the ADQ typically is identified in the project's QAPP.

Data Quality Assessment (DQA) is a statistical and scientific evaluation of data sets to determine the validity and performance of the data collection design and statistical analysis and to determine the adequacy of the data set for its intended use. In ORD, data quality assessments are limited to those projects for which formal data quality objectives were developed. Refer to EPA QA/G-9R (2), Data Quality Assessment: A Reviewer’s Guide, for more information about DQAs.

Laboratory Competency Assessment (LCA) is an external technical evaluation of laboratory operations. Competency means that an organization has the equipment, instrumentation, staff, and demonstrated analyst proficiency needed to generate valid environmental measurement data that meet the project needs. Refer to PPM 13.10 (10), Laboratory Competency Assessments for further information about ORD’s use of LCAs.

Readiness Review is a technical audit that is planned and performed prior to the initiation of a project to verify that project management has brought the facility and/or applicable technical systems to a state of readiness to begin the project. EPA has not traditionally used readiness reviews, but the principles can be used to ensure that all parts of an EPA program are in place and ready for the start of a project. TSAs can be scheduled to serve as readiness reviews.
